blocks.value: Judas Iscariot was one of the Twelve Apostles chosen by Jesus. Despite witnessing countless miracles and hearing Christ's teachings firsthand, he betrayed his Master for thirty pieces of silver.

In the Garden of Gethsemane, Judas identified Jesus to the arresting soldiers with a kissâ€”a sign of affection turned into a symbol of treachery. His betrayal set in motion the events of Christ's Passion and Death.

Overcome with remorse, Judas returned the silver and hanged himself (Matthew 27:3-5). His story serves as a warning about the dangers of greed, the hardening of the heart, and despair. Unlike Peter, who also denied Christ but repented, Judas did not turn to God's mercy.
